How I came back from the drug
slavery
One would'nt expect to find the
former daughter-in-law of a United
States Senator and the wife of an
army officer here in the women's
workhouse at (Wefare Island). Some
times as I sit upstairs, looking through
the bars to the river, all the scenes
in my crazy-quilt life grow and
fade away before my eyes. I thing of
the years I spent in (New-England)
with my sea-captain father; M my
student days at (Ward-Belmont); of my
garden debut at the winter garden; of
months spent in an army post in the
Philippines; and then of the last three
years, which I don't want to remember
but which crowding upon my mind.
1
I was looked in the prison under the
name of (Helene S..) That isn't my
name, but then it doesn't matter
what label one is arrested under.
On the stage I was known as (Helene
French; my present married name
is (Mrs Samuel Walker) Both stand
personalities which aren't real any
more which passed on progressive
death known in the drug habit.
There was every reason why I have
a happy life Certainly I had all
the raw-material for it. I had good
home surrounding; I had educational
advantages; and married well.
Bceause an army doctor in the
Philippines preferred to keep me
quit all day rather than to have
